38556504.review:
Very good. If you like top-down shooters and good soundtracks, you'll love it. 

You will feel like you're cheesing its system most of the time. The AI is not smart; things either make a beeline for you or forget that they've seen you, and they'll completely ignore the wall you're breaking down until the hole gives you both line-of-sight. 

However, it's got a few addictive loops to it. There's the whole "peeling the onion" thing, the enjoyable process of wearing down a heavy security force until you're easily picking off the last guys. There's the level checkpointing: five office floors followed by a boss (and unless you make it past the boss, you'll go back to the first office floor in this segment when you die). There's the constant hunts for incremental increases in your stats or the cash to buy them, and this means that death never feels like a waste; you go back to the hub, and get a chance to spend the cash you've found on upgrades so that you'll fare better next time.

I could just describe it as cyberpunk rogue-lite twin-stic shooter.
But I have to say more because this is one of THE BEST GAMES I have played. Ever.

Visual side of the game is just gorgeous. Eye candy.
Especially if you are from VHS era. Or you like cyberpunk from 80'. Or neons (There is NEON in game's name for a reason :)

Music is well suited and I can't say bad word about other sounds.


And gameplay is the part where this game shines the most.
You play as one of five classes: hacker, cyber psycho, soldier, assassin or techie. They differ and prety much everybody states that one of them is overpowered. Although it would be different class each time. They are well balanced - have strong sides and flaws - all you have to do is find the one that suits you and your playstyle the most.
Levels are generated ramdomly (with exeptions) and each playthrough would differ. They are themmed acoridngly to floor you are currently in (like living quarters, hospital, warehouse). And there is boss after each floor.
Enemies have different abilities, strong sides and weaknesses.

Colectibles are changing rules drastically - you can collect new weapons, energy consuming secondaries and cybernetic implants. You are also collecting money.

Only way to spend all cash is to... die. You can buy upgrades of health, damage, energy and luck. But in first place buy all slots for cyber-implants (max 10). Then choose new "asset" and try again.


After few tries (and upgrades) game will become easy enough to kill last boss and finish story.. or not?
It took me about 6-7 hours to do that. Although you can start over - to fight against stronger enemies, to find new items and special rooms and see how far you can go. Theoretically dificulty can grow infinitively.


It's really worth buying.

37783631.review:
A really good game in which the main loop (start, kill, loot, upgrade, die or kill the overseer, permanently upgrade) feels quite fair. 

There's variety in the levels (sometimes you need to find a key to open the elevator to the next level, sometimes you have to destroy a set number of items, other times you need to just get out alive), there's variety in the weapons you can use, variety in the perks you can equip, variety in the enemy types and variety in the character classes you can choose.

The only problem I have with the game is the way I always fall back to the same combination of class/weapon to make my life easier: a full clear takes me 2-3 hours and you cannot really save your progress mid-game (after you save and load the game you won't start exactly where you left off, but from the "hub" level without the weapon/perks/upgrades you equipped during the run), so I always tend to choose a class that gives me higher chance of survival, and a weapon with high precision/high damage to be able to complete the run without dying.

Anyway, that doesn't really take away any fun or challenge from the game, the more you progress the easier it will also be to screw up, but you will also feel more powerful.

[h1] ネオン色彩鮮やかな、ツインスティックシューター [/h1]

巨大アーコロジー「ネオンクローム」に潜入したハッカーが、倉庫に冷凍保存された義体をハックして、ネオコープ社の支配者が待ち受ける頂上階を目指す･･･というのがだいたいのストーリー（だと思う）。

ゲームとしてはしごく単純で、弾数無制限のショットに、ミサイルやグレネードなどの強力なサブウェポン、近接攻撃の3つだけ。サブウェポンを使用するとエネルギーゲージを消費するが、倒した敵がドロップするアイテムで、少しずつ回復させることができる。

またステルス要素があり、敵の背後から攻撃すると大きなボーナスを獲得できるのが面白い。近接攻撃で壁をブチ破って背後に回り込んだり、曲がり角で待ち受けて出合い頭に掃射したり･･･正面からでは倒しにくい堅い敵にステルスキルが決まると、実に気分がいい。
武装、スキルの種類も豊富だ。

建物は30フロア6層構造で、それぞれの面ごとに「エレベーターにアクセスするドアのキーを探す」、「指定されたオブジェクトをすべて破壊する」などのミッションをこなしていくもの。

ローグライクなのでマップは毎回ランダムに生成され、死んだら最初からやり直し。ただし層の最終フロアに待ち受けるボスを倒すと、その層をスキップして途中から始めることができる。
またプレイ中に稼いだクレジットで基本パラメーターを強化する要素があるため、何度か周回して稼げばクリアできる程度の難易度か。

オブジェクトをバリバリと破壊できる爽快感、武器とスキルのトレハン要素、ほどよい難易度とあってとにかく面白い作品。
もっとも、2周目の難易度はなかなかのものだ。

36215113.review:
The isometric point-of-view of [b][i]Neon Chrome[/i][/b] lends itself wonderfully to different play styles, including both run-and-gun and stealth. Both methods will cause some chaos and commotion amplified by a nearly completely destructible environment. The only exception to the destruction are any doors requiring keys to open. Otherwise, players are free to play how they would like without penalties either way.

While moving from floor to floor, players can unlock different weapons, abilities, and cybernetic enhancements as they move along. These upgrades also become available once the player dies. The player is sent to a staging ground where the anonymous hacker selects an asset and equips them with what has been found along the way. The more the player dives into the game, the more can be equipped at each new beginning. 

The flexible straightforward gameplay and the randomized repayable nature of [b][i]Neon Chrome[/i][/b] makes it worth a look for any fans of shooters.

[b]THE GOOD[/b]
- Simple but tried and true twin-stick shooter formula is fantastic
- Surprisingly strategic
- RPG and rogue like elements give welcome strategy

[b]THE BAD[/b]
- Environments look the same on nearly every level
- Bosses repeat

[h1]8/10[/h1]

DISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | [b][u]GREAT[/u][/b] | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

36205437.review:
Neon Chrome is a fantastically enjoyable twin-stick shooter and I heartily recommend it if you are in the mood for some old-school arcade action.

The setting is a very Judge Dredd-esque mega block where you control a series of cyberpunk agents and blast your way up the semi-randomly generated block until you reach the evil Overseer, unlocking new weapons, abilities and cyberenhancements as you go and earning credits to upgrade your agent's base stats. When your agent dies, you can pick from a new set of agents, each from one of several different classes and with a set of gear & abilities randomly selected from what you've unlocked before. Do well enough and you can have that new agent start from a higher floor, and each time you beat the Overseer it is like a "new game +" mode, where you and the enemies all get bonuses.

I have been having a stupid amount of fun with this game. The graphics are crisp and colorful, the controls are easy and responsive with a PC compatible X-Box controller, and it is just very satisfying overall. The difficulty curve, once you get used to it, is also just the right side of hard, where you feel like you have a handle on each enemy type but each encounter is still threatening and tense, and resources are always scarce.

There are some (very!) minor issues. The story is fairly basic and minimal. Sometimes the level RNG will generate rooms where your upgrade and loot containers are surrounded by explosive barrels, so it's almost certain every thing will blow up before you can get to it. On levels with walkways, the money and energy drops from the enemies will frequently fall off the side into the abyss. The game has some issues with certain graphics cards (like mine!) so if you play in full-screen it will often do a quick switch back to the Steam program and then back to the game, so you have to play in a window. And last, but not least, the sound effect for the normal doors sounds just like a melee "whiff" from a ton of other games, so I keep thinking there is a dude I've missed who is taking wild swings at me.

But regardless of minor problems, the rest of the game is just silly fun. And lots and lots of explosions.

36019217.review:
Rating: 8/10
Overview: Top Down Twin Stick Shooter Rogue 

The Good:
+ Always love cyberpunk aesthetic 

+ Like any good rogue lite game there are plenty of weapons, abilities and passive abilities to unlock.  Collecting money is also important because it allows you to upgrade stats permanently for future playthroughs.  

+ With all the passive abilities and weapons you can create some creative builds every playthrough, you can focus on offense, health, defense or explosive abilities 

+ A lot of the levels feature destructible walls, after a heavy firefight its cool to see almost everything destroyed. 

+ This game is a lot more forgiving than most other rogue games on Steam. Its very easy to pick up and play  

+ Can be played for short bursts or for long periods of time

+ Every time you beat the final boss the game gets harder, harder enemies, more health, more damage, however you are also rewarded with more money and thus buy more permanent upgrades. 

+ level editor and mods 

+ Great soundtrack 

The Average:
+/- There are only a few bosses and they are not that exciting. Bosses are supposed to be a bit more challenging than the regular gameplay, yet I found these bosses to actually be easier. 

The Bad:
- There is a lack of variety with the levels themselves. Although they are procedurally generated, they all feel the same. 

Conclusion: 
A great rogue twin stick shooter that is sure to please fans of both genres. I would love to see a sequel where more ideas are expanded upon to provide more variety within the gameplay.

A roguelike top-down shooter with procedural levels. Blast your way through walls & enemies with guns and cybernetic abilities. Install perks from cyber chambers and upgrade your character stats after each death. Can you stop the Overseer?

I love cyberpunk and top down shooters, so it's surprising that I haven't heard about this game earlier. Just got it in some Humble Bundle bundle and damn did I have some fun. It's your basic top down shooter with cyberpunk vibes. During your playthrough you permanently unlock cyber-implants that you can find on some levels plus you can level up dmg/hp/energy for $$$ found. Levels are randomly generated and every few floors you have fixed levels with bosses. Technically it's not very complex and there are only 4 bosses, but that's cool.

Because the execution is definitely on point. Shooting is fun, procedurally generated levels are fun, cybernetic enhancements are fun. Everything is really enjoyable. Well, if I'd had to find something I'd say the story, if we can even call it that, is nothing to write home about. But then it's a procedurally generated top down shooter and not an adventure game. It took me more than 10 hrs to complete the game twice, after each completion a higher difficulty is unlocked, and do some achievement hunting. And I'm still not bored, so that was money well spent.

I liked:
* that cyberpunk feel
* game is fun in general
* has that just-one-more-try/level feeling

I disliked:
* nothing really

Get this if:
* you like twin stick shooters

Don't get this if:
* you don't like twin stick shooters (it's that simple!)

総評としては大味だけど雰囲気のいいSTGRPG、問題がないとは言えないですが、独特の魅力があってお手軽な感じもいい感じのゲームでした。

35452357.review:
Neon Chrome is a game to play multiple times!

Welcome to the 80's, where everything is chrome and shines like neon. The atmosphere of the game is very adequate and the senses are flooded with music and images that take us to a skyscraper that is the seat of the organization that dominates the society. Your goal is to reach the top where the leader is and force him to surrender. You will do this by using clones and operatives specializing in incursions. Their control over these operatives is made through an equipment that lets them enter their minds through an operating system and data network.

I know, I know ... it's a lot like Matrix, Ghost in the Shell, Tron, Blade Runner, Total Recall and other Sci-Fi classics. But this is good! That is the proposal. The elements of these classics are all there. Like the Matrix immersion chair, the first Boss that reminded me of the end of Ghost in the Shell, the music and colors of Tron, the buildings of Blade Runner.

The art of NC is very well cared for to convey the right feel to this kind of story. Drones, computers, armed agents, lasers, neon lights (obviously!), high buildings where don’t see the ground, everything is there. The models are not very detailed. This is evident when you open the pause menu, but since distance of view leaves these models smaller, this is not a problem. They are varied types of characters that we can control and fit well the class to which they belong. Weapons vary by color and size (since the weapon models are very similar). The backgrounds are adequate too. The animations are interesting but not very varied. There could be a set and more stranded, but that does not affect the game so much.

The sound of the game is a show apart! The music score are perfect for the environment and nostalgia will affect you for sure. These are good-sized compositions that remind you of even those great movies I quoted up there. Look for the OST because it is very good. I'm listening here now! Sound effects are cool. Like animations, the effects could have a greater variation and personality, but they are good in general.

The gameplay is a top down shooter that requires you to watch out for enemy shots. Each weapon has a different amount of shots and reload time, and you will, over time, evolve your weapons making them more powerful and faster. There are different types of ammunition that affect enemies differently: drones are most affected by laser shots while plasma injures humans more. No spoilers! It's cool to find out how each enemy reacts with each weapon. (Although this does not vary its animation, what a pity!). The strategy involved in destroying apparatus and obtaining keys are at all stages. Some walls are destructible and others are transparent causing the enemy to see and chase you. But do not worry, they're not very smart. The game is procedural, but some stages mark your progress. One clever thing in this game that I noticed is that Bosses are very difficult when you reach them the first time, so you repeat the stages several times to upgrade your character and only then can you defeat him. Hmm interesting design! I can not forget to say that ogame allows local cooperate, which makes the game more fun!

Neon Chrome supports Mods and in a very organized way. The community has all kinds of things that teach you how to make different models and how to apply. This one I tested! And there are several other mods with pertinent changes that will please you.

In summary, NC is a fun and challenging game that will take you a few hours and there is also a DLC with a multiplayer arena if you feel good enough to go to war! I grew up in the 80's and got lost from the rest of the world playing Neon Chrome.

Long Live the Nostalgia! Go Play!
 
Art: 7/10        Sound: 8/10      Gameplay: 7/10      Fun: 8/10      Total: 7.5

35386750.review:
Fantastic polished progressive topdown shooter. Game is not very known for some reason but it's a gem.

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
- Multiple classes
- Pseudo random level generation
- Permanent progression (upgraded stats remain with you through death)
- New Game+ (up to 10)
- Graphically it looks good
- 99% bug free for me (the 1% being gold/energy drops falling outside of the level)
- Plays smooth

[h1]Con's[/h1]
- I was hoping for more content (I estimate about 5 to 15 hours of  playtime depending on how skilled you are). New Game+ adds more playtime but it's not really new content. I went to NG+3 and maxed the damage stat in about 10 hours total.
- Wish I could just hold down the melee button instead of having to spam it.
- Level entries on higher NG's are sometimes completely crowded with explosive enemies, resulting in a near-impossible level in some odd cases depending on your items.

[i]Note: if using a Logitech mouse, you can change the mouse-speed through there. I could not find this option ingame.[/i]

35335322.review:
Neon Chrome est un twin stick shooter qui reprends les codes du rogue like, dans un univers de SF genre blade runner/Brazil pour les inspirations de design. 
Plutot orienté action, le jeu consiste à gravir les étages d'une tour au sommet de laquelle vous vous confronterez à l'Overseer, le dirigeant du batiment, qui vous aura auparavant envoyé tous ses gardes a vos trousses.

Le jeu est clairement joli, ce qui n'est pas une constante pour ce genre de jeu, qui privilégie plutot la nervosité (dans le style  Enter The Gungeon ou Nuclear Throne par exemple).
Le gameplay est assez riche, puisque vous disposerez de tout un arsenal (sniper, fusil a pompe, mitraillette, pistolets lourds, lance roquette, molotov,...) et de différentes classes de personnages à choisir au début de chaque run. De plus, la possibilité de détruire l'environnement est ultra appréciable, et permet de jouer plus discretement (en défoncant des murs), fait rare pour cette catégorie de jeux.

Mention spéciale à la BO qui, quoiqu'un peu répétitive, met clairement dans l'ambiance globale de l'univers.

En terme de difficulté, le jeu est a la fois très punitif (lors des premières parties notamment) du fait de la barre de vie qui ne remonte pas avec le temps, et relativement plus facile d'accès lorsque vous comprenez les patterns des boss et ennemis communs.

Enfin, par rapport à la durée de vie, Neon Chrome propose un new game+, puis un new game ++,... Bref c'est assez fourni.

En bref, c'est clairement une réussite, et une valeur sure, et indé, alors que demande le peuple?

Neon Chrome Is basically a cyberpunk version of twin-stick shooters like Gauntlet, Helldivers, and Alien Swarm/Reactive Drop. You can play it solo or in 4-player coop. Lots of gear and upgrades, and endless replayability since the non-boss levels are procedurally generated.

This was on my wishlist for a long time, but I every time I thought about buying it, I first watched the gameplay video and was unimpressed by the simple graphics. So I repeatedly put it off. Now that I've finally played it I realize I was missing out. It's an awesome game, and once you start playing you completely forget about the simplicity of the graphics. It's easily as much fun as any of the other twin-stick shooters mentioned above, plus it comes with a level/mod editor. I wish I knew how to mod, becasue after playing it I had some ideas of how to expand the game.

Definitely worth the $15 price tag, and all the more impressive because the download is only 250 MB. In this day and age, it's hard to believe that a company can deliver so much entertainment in such a small package.

A rogue-like that doesn't feel like it. Neon Chrome oozes style, substance, and is insanely friendly to the player. Everything is simple and clean, with a great soundtrack, brilliant use of color and a firm grasp of the cyberpunk aesthetic. It's addicting and great fun, with the ability to pick up and play as you need to. You're not punished for needing to pause, minimize, or take a break and that really pushed it over the edge for me. It was a game that let me play it.

Despite all the pros, some of the cons are that some character classes feel definitively better than others, and that is the case with some guns, skills, abilities and modifications. There are a few I've never used and probably never would, even if I grinded to Overseer 100.0. Overall, when you find out what's good and what works you begin to enjoy the game three times as much as before and you're driven to starting from level 1 to make that badass character one that wipes the entire Neon Chrome megaplex.

I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys rogue-likes and those who may be able to tolerate a unique take on one while diving headfirst into the rainy neon grit of a proper cyberpunk universe.

35164480.review:
So far I'm digging this game. What initially drew me in was the aesthetic; this is a gorgeous display of cyberpunk. The gameplay itself surprised me: while most twin stick shooters I've played involve a lot of "run backwards and fire" strategy (and Neon Chrome certainly has its moments of that), many of the firefights involve careful use of cover and choke points. This is bolstered by the destructible terrain. Many objects and walls can be destroyed, allowing you to ambush enemies or flank their shields. The guns themselves have a decent variety, although I wish they dropped more frequently. There is also a nice assortment of enemies, each promoting different tactics. One caveat that this game has is, at least so far, it's not particularly difficult; the flip side of this is that I haven't had any moments where I felt the difficulty was artificial. Overall, I highly recommend Neon Chrome.

Updated 12/12/17 - I'm up to Overseer Level 7 (Overseer Levels being a New Game+ mode) and the challenge is getting real. The difficulty bumps up each time you beat the game, and can be dropped back down at any time. Everything in the game can be unlocked at more relaxed difficulties, but if you enjoy the core gameplay loop then it does get harder (theoretically) forever.

35121840.review:
Fun gameplay, no major annoyances. The cyberpunk presentation is cool as well. I beat it once, after about 6 hours, but it's possible to continue in New Game+ mode, and I might keep playing. It's a good game, but not an excellent one.

Neon Chrome is a top-down shooter with permadeath that you can play fast or slow, swooping in with guns blazing or picking off enemies slowly with stealth. That being said, using stealth is going to take a while. As you play through the procedurally generated levels, new enemies show up to keep things fresh, and there are four bosses distributed across the game. The bosses are okay, not frustrating but also not all that interesting.

The character progresses through weapon upgrades and biotech upgrades. The weapon upgrades are a simple level system, but you have to change your weapon to a different type to take advantage of the raising level. The biotech upgrades are gained from upgrade machines. When you find one of those, you get a choice of three upgrades of which you can pick one. Some are better, some are worse, but all of them are in some way relevant. As you play you unlock various new weapons, abilities and biotech upgrades that can from then on show up randomly anywhere, on the current and any future characters. Also, after you die you can upgrade various stats that make all your future characters stronger. And you can choose a starting weapon, ability and biotech upgrade for your next character, for a price. You can also enter the game at several checkpoints, but you will lack upgrades, so this is only really viable after playing for a while to upgrade your global stats.

It's quite a fun game, it looks cool, sounds cool, and doesn't waste your time. I recommend this for people who like top-down shooters. Due to the short game length I wouldn't pick it up at the current full price of 15€ though. I got it much cheaper from a Humble Bundle.

Gayet hoş, hızlı ve eğlenceli bir oyun. Satın aldığımda Crimson Land'ın yapımcısının olduğunu bilmiyordum, ki onu da vakti zamanında bol bol oynamışlığım vardır. Neon Chrome onun biraz daha geliştirilmiş, cyberpunk soslu hâli. 

Koskocaman bir binadaki bir hacker'ı yönetiyoruz ve hedefimiz kötücül yapay zekâyı yenip buradan kaçmak. Kahramanımız bu uğurda Matrix'in koltuklarını andıran bir aparata oturuyor ve dondurulmuş yüzlerce askerden birinin bedenini kriyopod deposundan çıkarıp salıyor binanın asker ve taret kaynayan koridorlarına. Her askerin farklı farklı özellikleri var; kimi daha keskin nişancı, kimi bilgisayarları hackleyebiliyor kimiyse vücuduna daha çok implant takabiliyor.

İmplant demişken, oyunda karakterinizin özelliklerini istediğiniz gibi değiştirebileceğiniz bir sürü teknolojik eklenti var. Seviye atladıkça oyun stilinize göre dilediğinizi seçiyor, ilerledikçe daha fazla seçeneğe ve silaha sahip oluyorsunuz. Bölümler de rastgele olarak oluşturuluyor, o nedenle her seferinde başka bir katı dolaşıyormuş gibi hissediyorsunuz. Bir tek boss savaşlarındaki katlar aynı, onlar da canınızı itinayla çıkardığından bundan şikayet etmeye fırsatınız olmuyor :)

34041719.review:
Kind of a mix between Hotline Miami, Rogue-Like, and Roleplaying game.

The game game is a top-down shooter, with an "infinite" gameplay. That means that while there's an end-game, you can repeat the whole process with higher difficulty, and since every floor is procedurally generated, every single experience will be different.

The gameplay is really nice if you take off Vsync in the game's files, guns are really fun to use, there are a few different classes of characters (of which you'll be able to pick between 3 everytime you die), the music is synthwave and really addictive, and the graphics are well done. It's a refreshing title that doesn't need too much thought to play, and I really liked it in short bursts. Also want to mention that there are a few unlockables that you might find in your playthrough; special weapons, abilities, normal weapons. Unlock them once, and they'll have a chance to drop in weapons crates/abilities pods/augmentations pods, making every single character a different customization and making it not repetitive.

Regarding the game longetivity, the devs have said that the usual player takes from 7 to 14 hours to finish one playthrough. I finished it in 5, and while I'm a good player, I don't think I'm incredibly gifted. If you're good at hotline miami you'll not have a lot of troubles in the game.

To the point; you collect credits that you can use before starting another round in permanent upgrades or weapons/abilities for your next character, and only your next character. It's a fun way to make the game easier, though I spent all my money on luck.

This game is a great short game, really fun and addictive, it's a shame I have a great backlog of over 20 games, otherwise I'd play another playthrough. I'll probably do it in the future.

7.5 / 10.

33917944.review:
I normally [i]do not[/i] like Rogue Like ... though [b]all[/b] classic action games on the old 8bit, 16bit and 32bit you could call Rogue Like. In most of those you had [b]more[/b]  then one life, or an HP Bar or multible Life with HP bar.

Nowadays, when you read Rogue Like ... it means [i]one[/i] life and then you start at zero all over again. And honestly, that sucks. Whats the point to play a long game in one sitting without dieing? To die is part of the experience in games. You don't do something right and you die, learning something in the process.

But Neon Chrome is not like a Rogue Like. In each run you can unlock allot things, like Skill upgrades, Weapons, Stats for your Avatar. You can just jump in and try to get as far as possible ... though without any upgrade at the start you probably can not beat the game ... or it is very hard.
There are so many cool things you can find, and once you die you don't feel as empty as you feel with other Rogue Like.

Not to forget, the Graphic is nice enough and the Soundtrack ... oh boy the Soundtrack. It fits in perfectly with the Graphic presentation and make you want to come back for more.

If you serarch a game, that you can play every now and then that is fun and rewarding ... and if you like Twinstick Shooters ... then you gotta try this one out.

32839791.review:
「ローグライク+トップダウンアクションシューティング」
・大まかな内容
あなたは監督官によって束縛を受けている。ネオンクロームオフィスビルにて監督官を制止させ現状から脱却せよ。

・初めに
主人公のいる部屋には、金銭によってパラメータを上げる端末機が個別で設置されている。
他にもスキルやアビリティ、武器を購入する端末機があり、装着した状態で始めることができる。

戦闘エリアには、自身の頭脳を介して操作する義体で突入する。
初めに複数のクラスから3種のクラスをランダム構成で生成する
(初めにアイテムを購入した場合は、購入したアイテムが装着されている)。
そこから好みのクラスを選択し、６区画あるビルの最上階にいる監督官を撃破することが目的である。
区画にはいくつかのエリア分けがなされており、カードキー集めが主体だが爆発物処理などもある。
ちなみに、区画ごとに待ち構えているボスさえ倒してしまえば、区画別で始めることが可能なので「死んでしまうと初めから」という問題はない。
また金銭は持ち帰ることができるので、下準備をして再挑戦することが出来る。

・クラスに関しては、プレイスタイルが変化するものもあり多様性に富んでいる。
ハッカーの場合は、紫色の宝箱や扉を解錠することが可能。
アサシンの場合は、視界アイコンが表示され影に身を潜めることができる。
他に、体力が低くなる代わりに自動修復のアーマーを装備したクラスや、盾で身を守れるクラスもある。

・狙って撃つシューティングとして楽しめられる上、ローグライクとしても楽しめられる。
弾数に制限がないので、撃ちまくることが可能。スキルを複数装備することにより効果を楽しむこともできる。
戦闘エリアに突入する前にお気に入りのスキルを装着することが可能なので、運要素に楽しみが持てなくなるものの意識的に組み合わせを楽しむことができる。
例としては、エクスプロージョンショット(リロード後、初発が爆発弾になる)スキルと、高速リロードのスキルを組み合わせた状態で、さらに炎症ダメージ追加のスキルを装着しながらアサシンプレイなどがある。
運要素が原因でボスに歯が立たないといった問題もないので、ローグライクとして観ても上手なブレンド作品である。

協力プレイはエリア内で片方が死んでしまっても、次のエリアで80％の体力を持って復活できる。ただスキルは無くなるので死なないよう効率よく進めていきましょう。

・気になった点
敵の頭が悪い。あり得ない動きをしたり、気づいているはずなのにどこか見て見ぬふりをしたり、ガバガバ警備です。
クラスごとに差別化を図りたかったのか、ハッカーでしかローグライクとして楽しめないかも。
武器の性能が面白くない。あり得ない形状の武器とかがない。この種の敵には何パーセントかダメージアップのようなものばかり。

◇結論としては、純粋に楽しかったです。どのクラスを選んでもクリアできます。
隠し要素もあるようで、クリアした後そのまま「強くてニューゲーム」もできますし、ワークショップにてハードで挑戦的なものに挑んでも楽しいです。協力プレイもしましたが盛り上がったので、お気に入りの作品です。

32620613.review:
Добротный rogue-lite от авторов Crimsonland. Рука авторов видна сразу, механика стрельбы очень похожа. Но если бы игра просто копировала Crimsonland, то покупки бы не стоила. Однако есть серьезные отличия, которые достойны вложения денег.

Важных составляющих две: перестрелки в закрытых, но разрушаемых пространствах, и добротное киберпанковское оформление всей игры, от элементов декора до музыки. Поклонники synthwave'а разочарованы не будут: хотя и обошлось без шедевров, но сандтрек приятный. Если хочется чуть-чуть разбавить - подтяните OST из бестолкового Kill to Collect, он отлично подходит.

Сюжет есть, но его меньше чем хотелось бы. Концовка хоть и логичная но смазанная. При таких декорациях вполне реально было бы сделать сюжетную составляющую погуще. Кстати покажут сюжет только при первом прохождении, не пропускайте надписи.

Представлен богатый выбор оружия, россыпь навыков и умений. Открывается все постепенно, при обследовании уровней и специальных ответвлений от них. Есть перманентная прокачка основных параметров (практически бесконечная). Где-то за 3-4 прохождения реально вскрыть всё навыки и оружие. К сожалению балансу уделено недостаотчно внимания, и часть оружия и навыков к моменту открытия практически бесполезны в связи с постоянным переходом на повышенную сложность. Впрочем полезных навыков все равно больше чем способен утащить самый «вместительный» класс. Баланс можно подкрутить отличными модами из Мастерской, фанаты стараются.

Кстати о классах. Их аж четыре штуки, и один из них даже рассчитан на скрытное прохождение. Интересно, но недоработано. Бесшумным убийцей реально воспользоваться только к 4-5му прохождению.

Возвращаясь к перестрелкам в закрытом разрушаемом окружении. Это основная фишка, напрямую влияющая на игровой процесс в целом и к тому же влияющая позитивно. Пролом в стене позволяет обойти противника и получить небольшое, но ценное преимущество в перестрелке. Neon Chrome наверное самая близкая к х/ф «Dredd» (2012) игра. Этот Dredd-feel настолько силен что авторы пилят на том же движке игру JYDGE (угадай лицензию, на которую не хватило денег). А пока что довольствуемся Neon Chrome и разносим целые этажи в труху.

Итого: поклонникам Crimsonland и Dredd'а брать по скидке. Надолго игра не затянет, но 4-5 вечеров точно скрасит.

I've played this game for ~32 hours, and am currently working on the third playthrough (aka. 3.0).

Initially, I bought it because I liked the game's premise, and the graphics made it look interesting.  What kept me coming back, actually,  was achievment chasing.  The game is fairly easy to play, but the some of the achievments were surprisingly difficult.

Consider that I tend to like easy-ish games because they're casual, but I obsess on challenging achievments.  Doesn't seem all that consistent, does it?  And yet this game has a good blend of both - and that's what hooked me.

These days, Neon Chrome should be fairly inexpensive, but I think it's still a better than average value.  The replayability is impressive (to me); you can choose a different style of play each time you boot it up, and yet accumulate statistics in the form of purchased upgrades, no matter which character you play.  After beating the game, you have the option of increasing the difficulty yo the next levelk, which increases dropped rewards, etc.

Overall, Neon Chrome delivers casual fun in a way that kept me playing for longer than I'd planned on playing.  That's gotta count as a successful game.

31762304.review:
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]The shortest possible way to describe the gameplay of Neon Chrome would be the following math equation: Neon Chrome = Rogue Legacy - Super High Difficulty (early on) + Hotline Miami + Cyberpunk Setting. That's a bit too basic, though, and not 100% accurate, of course, so I'll go into a bit more detail. 

If you didn't already know, the big difference between a rogue-like and a rogue-lite, is that although both give you randomized maps and you start the game over if you die, rogue-[i]lites[/i] give you some form of progression/unlocks that is saved between runs. Neon Chrome is the latter, letting you keep the money that you picked up from enemies and loot boxes, and essentially letting you continue past bosses you have beaten, using the money you earned on your run to purchase persistent (permanent) stat upgrades for all future runs. This is much like the system used in Rogue Legacy, though I actually found this game to be a lot more fair and designed to encourage tactics more so than to simply abuse the player.

That leads me into the Hotline Miami comparison. No, you don't just die any time you're hit, but I'm referring to the real-time tactical aspects of that game. While some players may have run in like a screaming barbarian, clubbing everything and zooming around rooms trying not to get hit while taking on an army of guys and being shot at, I tended to be stealthy, going into a room and killing enemies before I was seen, thus reducing the odds of death and systematically getting myself closer to victory. You can do that in this game, too. It's unlikely you'll go unseen, but you can minimize the number of enemies who have seen you at times and use doors as bottleneck killzones, and corners with your laser sight to line up easy kills.

Playing like this helps to even out the deficiencies in your stats or in your gear, while the persistent upgrades give an enjoyable "vengeance" sensation while wiping the floor with enemies who used to make your life suck when doing another run. The randomized parts of the game consist of enemy placement, map layout, and per-run weapons and cybernetic implants. The former come in a variety of well-designed weapons you'll grow to learn the strengths and weaknesses of, while the latter give you amazing bonuses, such as 50% max health capacity bonus, +100% manual reload speed, immunity to mines, 35% HP recovery upon completing a floor (so good!), and many more. On each run, you get a new character (random 3 to pick from a la Rogue Legacy) with pros and cons to him or her (Hacker rocks when trying to make lots of cash!). Try several character classes and see which one(s) you enjoy most.

Did you find a weapon you like? Why in the world would you ever bother opening another gun box when you have the gun you want to finish the game with? Well, the developer was very clever here. At the beginning of the game, it's a level 0 gun, with pretty awful stats. If you open a gun box, not only do you get a new gun you can choose to take or leave, but [i]all[/i] gun drops on that run are now leveled up higher, and thus have better stats! Why visit weapon upgrade machines if you're using a gun you want to ditch ASAP? More brilliance on the developer's part. Using the upgrade machine [i]also[/i] levels up all future gun drops on that run. If you go visit all gun boxes and upgrade machines, max level guns should be dropping by end game, which really helps out. I could go on about the things you find to unlock more things, but it would just be rambling.

A successful run in which you kill everything and collect everything will probably be about an hour and a half in length, and it goes by pretty quickly. If you die and finished a boss, you can start over around level 5, 11, 17, 22, or 29 (I'm sure I'm off on a few of those, sorry!), by stepping into an elevator with the appropriate section number (1 through 6), with each one lighting up after you beat that chapter's respective boss. The bosses are pretty simple but well-designed in their attacks and movements (I love the second boss). Personally, though, I played from the beginning whenever I died, because it's so rewarding if you open all the gun boxes so you have higher-leveled weapons by end game, and you can breeze through the easier, earlier levels while unlocking more things for future runs and getting more cash.

An hour and a half long if you play it well? I'm sure most people will need a few attempts to win, but yeah, it's not a super long game. If you're one of those folks who sees value in game length, though, this is absolutely a "new game plus" game. The big screen on the right in your starting room says "Overseer 1.0" but if you win the game, it shows 2.0, do it again, and 3.0, etc. You can use a computer console in a room on the left of the starting room which shows you a bar graph of the various stats in levels, including enemy HP and damage, as well as loot amount. The loot amount goes reeeeally high when going from one difficulty to the next, giving you much, much more money per kill and loot box, letting you get your stats maxed in a jiffy.

But what in the world do you spend your money on between runs if you've maxed out all your stats? You spend it on per-run guns and per-run cybrnetic implants. At the top of the starting room are three consoles which let you purchase and level up certain guns for money, as well as take specific cybernetic implants of your choosing and a combat ability of your choosing instead of relying on randomness on future runs. Each successive implant costs much more money than the last, but it's really worth it to get the must-have ones for your playstyle (max HP and health recovery stuff for me because I'm pretty terrible!). The developer really thought this stuff through and clearly put a lot of time and effort into it.

Long story short, here we have a top-down shooter in which you can be somewhat tactical along the lines of Hotline Miami, with persistent purchasable stats between runs like in Rogue Legacy. It's got a nice cyberpunk asthetic, and the developer clearly cared more about making the game be fun than a pain in the rear. It can be challenging in your first couple of hours, before getting any stat gains, and before all of the glowy cyberpunk things in levels finally register with your brain so you know what is a decoration and what is something vital you need to interact with, but eventually your skill, even if crappy like mine, will likely allow you to triumph with some nice persistent stat gains between runs making up for your weaknesses.

I planned on "gameplay" being the final segment of my review and actually wrote it first, but it turns out there was so much to say that I'm basically out of room for everything else! Let's hit up the other main points of the game in rapid-fire mode!

[h1]Story[/h1]
If I had a pie chart of the relevancy of each aspect of the game, story would be 1% of the pie at best. It's not awful, but it's pretty forgettable and just kinda there. Story is normally a massive motivator for me, but the gameplay was of such a high caliber that I was completely fine with the lack of interesting plot.

[h1]Graphics/Art Style[/h1]
I like the look of the game, though my only complaint is that for my first maybe 2 hours, everything is so glowy that it's easy to thing decorations are important objects in the game world when they're not, or to confuse important objects as being decorations when they're not. It all clicked with me after a while!


[h1]Music/Sound[/h1]
One of the human enemies dying sounded kinda like a sergeant from '90s Doom dying at times, so that put a smile on my face, and the music was decent. I actually adored a few brief parts/sets of notes in a couple of the songs.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Outta room! I really liked this when i thought I wouldn't. I tend to dislike most rogue-y games and top-down shooters aren't a big draw for me, so this game is all the more impressive. :D

31679936.review:
非常好玩爽感的快餐游戏。
游戏的玩法和质感看标签和视频差不多就知道了，另外死了之后身上的钱并不会丢失所以玩起来更接近刷刷刷而不是死亡惩罚严重的roguelike。
可强化程度非常高（大概血量和伤害都能到5倍吧）而且很便宜，不太需要刻意刷钱就可以通关。
敌方有视野设定而我们是上帝视角，可以打得很猥琐，游击穿墙开门杀等等。也可以打得很刚那就是拼强化程度和躲弹幕能力了。
建议用键鼠玩，这样走位稍微没那么灵活但是射击方便很多，尤其是穿墙瞄准的时候。
五个职业：（17年5月，不过游戏应该不会再更新了）很多属性就是一个被动技能的事情就不讨论了，聊核心特性。
Hacker 有种钦定的感觉（你在基地里的职业显示就是elite hacker），很多箱子或者机关都注明了只有Hacker能开。附带的无人机还凑合吧不本质。
Techie 最弱的职业。特性是自带一个20点可以自动恢复的护盾，这个护盾也就你一点等级都没有的时候有点用，后期你快1000血，敌人一个火箭弹打70多轻松破盾。如果只是护盾没用就算了，为了“平衡性”考虑，techie自带-20%血上限的负面属性，太伤了。
Assassin 在没有光的地方隐身，玩起来可以非常猥琐。2层可以解锁一个被动技能在不动的时候隐身，配合起来更加神奇。
Cyber Psycho 核心特性是多两个被动技能slot，适合那些从一层开始准备打到满被动通关的人。还有近战加强不无小补。
Corporate Soldier 15%伤害立竿见影，至于那个减少25%正面伤害连鸡肋都不算吧。
刷图用Hacker，想通关用Psycho，特殊情况用Assassin（例如那个一整关不被看见的成就）。
基地在强化上面一点的地方可以花一点点钱选择下一次玩的初始武器、能力和一个被动（二周目可以选两个依次类推），对build快速成型很有帮助。
最后讲几个关键的被动吧。
刷钱用的：
Omnitech Floor Bonus （2层解锁） 每关给你关数*100的钱，少于500的话给500。一次通关这个被动大概可以给3w多，进去之前花300买一个这个，只要过一关就回本了。
Crashware Gib Money （4层解锁） 每炸死一个人给你150，配上一个带爆炸能力的初始武器刷起来飞快。缺陷是爆炸类武器很多场景里不是很好用。
Omnitech Energy Compensator （4层解锁） 每关结束的时候给你剩下的能量*5的钱。属性高级之后每关给3千，最后折算下来大概是Floor Bonus给的两倍，推荐。
通关用的：
Mediplus Floor Heal （1层解锁） 整个游戏里最适合莽夫的被动能力，每关结束时回复35%的血，极大提升了容错率，血量级别高了之后可以随便莽。
Omnitech Deflector Field （5层解锁） 莽夫挚爱之二，每有50点能量减少5%伤害（最高40%）。40%减伤如果再配上回复能力，只要不作死基本死不了。
我第一次通关用的build核心是Armocore Explosive Bullets+Neurocore Reload Booster，每个弹夹的第一发加伤害和两倍速手动装填，每打一枪就重新装填。第一发附带一个小的explosive效果打护盾兵和物免云团都有奇效，配合burst类型武器非常爽快。
隐藏解锁可以看社区指南，全成就不难。

I really like this game.  It's nothing super fancy, but it does what it does very well.  It's the standard find keys, open doors, grab loot, and get out kind of game.  The meat of this game is in the upgrades and varied enemies.  At the start of the game, you get the bare minimum - a weapon and special power of limited choice.  However as you loot, you keep the $.  So when you die, you go back to the main level and can purchase upgrades/enhancements.  So, there's no need to get get frustrated - you are always improving your situation even when you die.

It's possible to hang back, get a feel for an area, think what you're going to do, and then execute.  So, it's not always just straight shooting ... but it can be.

A+ for making me want to kill an Overlord I've never met, heard much about, or watched their reign of tyranny.  Stupid Overlord.

31495439.review:
I haven't played for long but I believe I have a good enough understanding to write a review. I will most certainly update this as I accrue more playtime. Thank you for your patience
========================================
Core Gameplay
----------------
The game plays like a more forgiving hotline miami but feels like your classic twin stick shooter, albeit with much more customisation and abilities. You choose a character from a pool of 3 (although later on you can choose weapons, characteristics and abilities that are certain to appear in your pool for that run) and they are your "asset" for that run. Your aim: destroy the overlord on floor 30. You must fight (or stealth) your way through while collecting weapons and abilities and upgrade your loot level/current weapon.

Items/Abilities
---------------
There are a lot of weapons and abilities to unlock. The unlock system is very balanced and you will find yourself wanting to start from an earlier section just to try and pick up unlocks that you've missed! Abilities are awarded by entering a chamber that gives you an ability that you've selected from a pool of 3 (4 if your class is cyborg) and you have to be quite tactical with your abilities as you can only have a set number of them

Gameplay (In-Depth)
----------------------
There's rarely a dull moment. Whether you're dodging turrets, fighting robot spiders or trying to get behind those GODDAMN RIOT SHIELDS you'll cherish the times you get to stop for breath. You can upgrade weapons by finding loot caches and you also upgrade your loot level which determines how good future gun drops for that run will be. Enemies do not spawn too frequently nor too slowly which is excellent. You always feel as though you are progressing as well which is excellent. Also, there is a save mechanic (although it's not obvious, exiting saves your progress). Also, the environment is destructible so that's pretty neat :P

*Overall Rating*
---------------
Gameplay - 8
Soundtrack - 7
Graphics - 8
Controls - 10
Story - 7
Replayability - 9
Overall - 8.5

Conclusion
------------
An excellent example of how top-down should be done. Even though the story is somewhat lackluster (although I can't really judge given my tiny playtime) it's an exceptional game that is worth the price!

TL;DR 8.5/10, worth the money, feels like Hotline Miami but better

31375312.review:
[h1]Неонова різня[/h1]

Хто з геймерів не чув про таку легендарну гру як Crimsonland? Кубометри кров’яри, ядерні вибухи і тисячі монстрів… Ех, ностальгія.
І хоча студія видала нову частину найм’яснішої стрілялки всіх часів і народів, але ефект вже був не той. Невеликі косяки в інтерфейсі, складні квести через відсутність прокачки (виправлено патчем), дехто жалівся на переробку перків та зброї… Тому не думаючи довго, розробники прикрутили власникам гри ще й оригінал. Здавалось би, ось воно – щастя! Але 10tons пішли далі. 

Уявіть крімс під соусом кіберпанку та неону, приперчений структурованими рівнями з перешкодами (які можна знищувати), абсолютно новою зброєю і перками. Уявили? Тепер до цієї і так палаючої суміші додайте roguelike правила, прокачку параметрів персонажа (яких, до речі, декілька) і абсолютно нових ворогів… Що вийшло?

А в результаті ми маємо м’ясний екшн. Не такий кривавий, як славетний пращур, але з сюжетом, новою моделлю розвитку і трохи зміненим геймплеєм. 

Почнемо з сюжету. Наш протеже – безіменний хакер. Він вирішив покласти край правлінню головного наглядача міста Neon Chrome, який раптом вирішив, що він тут цар і бог. Проте злісний гад не підкинув руки до гори і не зліз зі свого сідала. Натомість він пообіцяв вирахувати нашого «ботана» по IP з не дуже гарними наслідками для останнього. На цьому моменті навчальна місія закінчується і починається гра.

Кожна місія стартує з лігва головного героя. В ньому ми можемо підкачати основні характеристики (здоров’я, сила зброї, удача, енергія і кількість слотів під перки), затаритись зброєю, активними і пасивними здатностями для персонажу. Добре підготувавшись до всього, наш хоробрий хакер… ні, не бере зброю в руки, чіпи в голову і не летить стрімголов форматувати дупу поганцю. Він сідає в крісло. Натомість з капсули вилазить персонаж (може мати одну з 6 спеціалізацій), який і буде пробиватись з вірним стволом через ворогів до фіналу. І ось тут починається найвеселіше.

Всього нас відділяє від титрів 36 поверхів-рівнів, які згруповані по 5х зонах, перехід на які охороняють боси. На кожній зоні нас чекатиме купа біомаси і бойовий металобрухт, який спить і бачить себе на звалищі. Варто віддати розробникам належне – рівні вийшли насиченими: ящики з лутом, термінали, обороні турелі, лазери, міни тощо. Також є шанс випадіння незвичайного модифікатора: наприклад, багато вибухівки, наявність одного дуже сильного ворога, велика за розміром територія тощо. 

Про ворогів варто сказати окремо. Якщо коротко – чим далі в ліс, тим грубші партизани. Вставлятимуть нам палки в колеса прості солдати (з щитом, добре озброєні, гренадири, гранатометники), неповороткі, але живучі і смертоносні кіборги, різні види дронів і ще пара типів вороже налаштованих посіпак наглядача, не кажучи вже про босів. Не густо, але вжарити наші булки товариство ще й як може.

Але не існує проблеми, яку б не міг вирішити арсенал різної зброї, від якої у більшості фанатів Крімсу виступить сльоза від ностальгії: узі, дробовик, автомат, Гаусс, кулемет… Всі пукавки діляться на 4 категорії: вогнепальні, лазерні, плазмові та іонні. Також окремо є цілий клас раритету: базука, Гаусс, паяльна лампа тощо. Кожен знайде щось під свій стиль гри.
Але що робити, якщо вороги стали сильнішими і наш автомат перетворюється в водяний пістолет? Відповідь – шукати схрони зі зброєю або спеціальні точки для покращення параметрів ствола. Чим більше «ничок» знайдено, тим кращу зброю будемо мати.

10tons не були б собою, якби не напхали в гру купу активних здібностей і пасивних покращень, які відкриваються з проходженням. Так, тепер тут є можливість не тільки давати гашетку до посиніння пальців, але й використовувати різні фінти типу розкидання гранат, підствольника, ракет, паралізації механічних/живих опонентів. Список далеко не повний. В пасивках теж повний порядок: купа здатностей на будь-який смак і стиль гри, починаючи від «фарму» кредитів і закінчуючи покращенням рукопашки (так, тепер можна втулити прикладом самому. Прощавай, перк Mr Melee). Відкриваються нові плюшки у спеціальних терміналах на рівні. Також є окремі камери для активізації перків. Одразу попереджаю, що деякі елементи пейзажу не витримують затяжних перестрілок і вибухів. Термінали, що відкривають нову зброю і перки - не виключення.

Музика також не підкачала. Synthwave треки ідеально вписуються в атмосферу неонового майбутнього.

З мінусів – survival за окрему плату. $2.90 за можливість повимахуватись прямизною рук – відносно невелика ціна, але тим не менше. Також є лише 3 активних бонуси. Але я підозрюю, що розробники просто подбали про баланс.

Вердикт. Це Крімс? Ні. Це весело? Ще й як. Реіграбельно? Так. 
Гра варта до придбання не тільки на розпродажі, але і за повну ціну.

As a huge fan of twin-stick shooters (even though I prefer to use the mouse and keyboard for these games), I saw this and got very, VERY excited, and imagine my excitement when I found out that these guys also made Crimsonland, one of my favourite games of all time.

I'm an 80's kid (born 1983), and I'm passionate about the styles that the 80's and 90's created. Neon Chrome takes the music and artistic theme from the 80's that many of us know and love (Think "Kung Fury" for an idea of the style I mean. Kung Fury nailed it too), handed us a gun, packed a top-down level with angry soldiers and robots, firmly pat us on the butt and told us to "Stick it to 'em".

The controls are tight and responsive, the gameplay starts out hectic but doable, and the upgrade system makes the difficulty curve your own responsibility!  If you loved Crimsonland but wanted more explosions and bright, hot neon pink, stop reading this review and go buy a copy of the game. You won't regret it.

The music is gloriously well written for the style of the game, and the title screen theme is now part of my soundtrack to life, so even if the game itself doesn't tickle your pickle, it's worth it for the music.

30963659.review:
Neon Chrome is honestly very good.  It succeeds as a twin-stick shooter and as a roguelite.  As a twin-stick shooter it steals many of the best mechanics and basic gameplay feel from 10tons' own much earlier classic Crimsonland, but adds destructible environments, special attacks, and rudimentary stealth.  Also your character is actually much sturdier than in Crimsonland, which is funny for a roguelite but it fits the format better since you don't heal up between levels.

As a roguelite, it has a gradual perk unlocking system that makes the binding of isaac look incredibly detailed by comparison, but actually, the high-level unlocks are obviously intended to allow scope for a little bit of a "build" aside from simple max dps.  Simple stuff like "shots have 15% chance to stun enemies" + "stunned enemies take double damage".  Between runs you spend the money you earned on permanent boosts to damage, or perk slots, yada yada rogue legacy upgrade your castle we've all seen it.  It's all done very well here.

If you enjoy roguelites, it's not as fun as the binding of isaac but currently, in my opinion, no roguelite is really trying to compete with that.  Short of TBoI, this one is about as fun as they get.  If you enjoy twin-sticks, well, this is crimsonland in roguelite form.

30334619.review:
If Hotline Miami, Binding of Isaac, Smash TV, and Blade Runner all had a baby then that baby would be Neon Chrome. You might say to yourself: three video games and one popular sci-fi movie can't make a baby. OK, fine. Maybe Neon Chrome is more like an abomination unto nature.  

Say what you will. At 15 bucks there's a lot to like about Neon Chrome. It's shiny. There's a ton of replay value. And the combat system rewards leveling via multiple-playthroughs without feeling grindy. That's a tough line to walk and Neon Chrome does some Fred Astaire ^#$@ on that line. What I'm trying to tell you is that the core gameplay here is great. 

The boss battles are anti-climatic, the voice acting is Saturday morning cartoon level, and some of the graphics look like they were built from Lego knock-off brands.

But much like the beloved creme egg (or I guess...all eggs) the quality center of rougelike gameplay awaits you. If you like top-down shooters or any of the other baby-making stuff I mentioned earlier then this game is for you.

Also, you must uninstall if you had to google Fred Astaire to read this review.

29761367.review:
Simple. Lonely. Desperate. Sparse 80s decor and lots of rain.

Ghost in the Shell + Frozen Synapse + F.E.A.R. + System Shock + NeuroVoider

With bossfights imported from Metal Gear but with the serious character of an Angband throwdown.

This is a game is a twin-stick shooter about the ballet of CQB. You manually push a cybernetically enhanced pawn across a Frozen Synapse-like landscape after some sort of bizzare robot uprising / AI mental takeover. Some of the pawns are great, and here is a game where you can play a cyber-ninja in thermoptic camo, equipped with seeker rockets, a super-sword and a repeating shotgun with 24 rounds in the mag.

It is about the long and lonely road through a very large building, one room entry at a time. It is intensely repetitive but never boring. The enemies are kind of dumb but that does not make it easy, and there is a good justification in the setting. (It's pretty questionable if they're fully themselves. You are a brainjacked meat puppet yourself, so it's got a certain abstract game-within-a-game aspect to it.) 

The way the enemies behave makes it almost a procedural puzzler at points, then you mess up and it's wild gunfire and swinging monokatanas. Bossfights are mostly positional puzzles / position control challenges, however, the bosses do have attacks that will insta you so don't get complacent.

Worth your time if you wish you could take part in a lot of infantry combat in the milieu of Ghost In The Shell.

29668706.review:
[h1]Neon Chrome[/h1]
[b]Developer[/b]: 10tons Ltd
[b]Publisher[/b]: 10tons Ltd

[b]Introduction[/b]
==========
I honestly don't remember where I got this game from, but I am so glad a friend mentioned it to me. Once I gave it a try, I was hooked for several days straight! I usually don't binge rogue-like games, but a very select few have managed to grab my attention. Neon Chrome is one of them.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
==========
Neon Chrome is a cyberpunk top-down rogue-like twin stick shooter. You are an operative trying to take down a corporation called Neon Chrome, that's run by a ruthless Overseer. The premise revolves around sending your operative's consciousness into an "asset", sort of like in James Cameron's Avatar film. You then use this asset to navigate through the many floors of the Neon Chrome building, fighting your way to the Overseer at the top. There are a variety of weapons and enhancements to help you mow down the hordes of robotic enemies and guards that you'll ve facing.

As this game a rogue-like, expect to die. A lot. However, the money and experience you gain each run will help you progress further and further each run. You'll learn how certain enemies move and behave, their attack patterns, and the best tactics/weapons to use against each. Money collected can be spent on permanent stat upgrades, or even to pre-equip yoru next asset with weapons and enhancements of your choice. Every so often, usually at random, you'll come across special pods that bestow cybernetic boosts. These boost gives you special abilities or increase your stats by a large margin. For example, there is one that increases your HP by 50% and your speed by 25%. You keep these boosts for the entirety of each run once found (and they can be unlocked and found again later!), but they are lost if you die. 

The Neon Chrome building is full of procedurally generated levels filled with traps, locked doors, and things that go boom. Almost everything you see can be blown up or destroyed....including precious loot boxes. Thin walls can be destroyed, but thick walls cannot. Locked doors can only be opened with keys, and these keys are either hidden in a room or held by a special Keymaster guard that must be defeated in order to obtain the key. You'll find all sorts of loot boxes, which usually contain money or energy tabs, which replenish your store of energy that is used on special attacks. Every 5 floors you'll unlock a "checkpoint", where you can start your next run from if you die. 

[b]Graphics[/b]
==========
The overall look and feel of Neon Chrome is amazing. Very vibrant and colorful. Cyberpunk influences everywhere. I love the art direction. It's not super detailed, but it's good enough. The game works with what it has, and excels at what it aims to do. However it can sometimes be hard to keep track of your character amidst the explosions and ammo flying around. Different weapon types (laser, plasma, etc) have different colored projectiles, most enemies get a new color when you meet a new variant, and power-ups/collectibles are very well defined and easy to spot. Keymasters are clearly labeled with a big red "KEYMASTER" over their heads, and later on stronger, more dangerous guards have their names over them as well, some of the ones I remember seeing were "CHRIS", "SCOTT", and "LENNY".

[b]Sound and Music[/b]
==========
I love this game's soundtrack!!! There's a few different tracks, and they all have a different feel and energy to them. Boss music gets you pumped (like it should). Each floor has a different theme to it, and it changes when you move to a new floor. Overall the rest of the game sounds great. Explosions are awesome, even if they are your latest cause of death (and they will be quite often). Your different weapons types all sound different as well, so you can oftentimes tell what kind of weapon your opponents have just by listening to the sound and the rate of fire.

[b]Performance[/b]
==========
I have no complaints here. The game runs nigh perfectly. I did not experience any problems whatsoever, even when there was total chaos on-screen. No dips in performance, freezes, or FPS loss. I played the game with my Logitech F310 controller, and it felt great. Left stick to move, right stick to aim, R2 to fire my gun, L2 to use my special ability, and L1 to break walls or smack things in the face with the butt of my gun. Simple, right? It's an effective control scheme and works very well.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
==========
Neon Chrome is an excellent rogue-like/twin stick shooter. Challenging, fun, and in my opinion one of the better games to come out last year. I could kick myself for not having tried it sooner!  

[b]Gameplay Demo[/b]
==========
https://youtu.be/c8rYNO9SUuE

[b]Nerd House Verdict[/b]:
==========
[h1][b]Highly Recommended[/b][/h1]

A while back, a buddy and I were on a couch co-op kick, Neon Chrome seemed perfect and it was.  Our first several attempts were cut short as we constantly grenaded each other. We learned the way the AI operated in enough circumstances that we could trap them minimize our damage taken, and...cruel as it sounds....it was fun.  Running those poor bastards into un-winnable situations where we waited, weapons at the ready.  We fell out of Neon Chrome after maxing our upgrades and unlocking everything (except for the last Cyberware...which I STILL don't have....dammit)  and we moved on to other projects.  However, Overseer 4.0 sat there in his chair....mocking me.  I had made it to floor 23 on a solo run...I could get him...I could kill him.  I obsessed over getting enough credits to fund a maxxed out run from the bottom to the top.  If I was going to overthrow that maniacal a**....I was going to do it right.   And I did.  But then there was overseer 5, and 6....Now I am 56 hours deep and I have met with my greatest foe.

Overseer 8.  He has consistently shut me down with waves upon waves of troops, and a Caretaker that seems nigh indestructable.  This game truly is just a series of processes to me now.  I have reached the point in this game where others stop seeming fun, and yet I play on.  I know the numbers just get higher, nothing really changes anymore...but I need to know.....just how many Overseers are there?  When does it end?!  When have I won?!!?!

Resounding Recommendation

A solid top-down twin-stick shooter with a colourful palette to suit its sci-fi theme. It is well thought out and executed. The randomised level generation is good quality and there are unlocks and special levels to inject just enough content to keep you from getting bored.

You can get bored as the levels become very samey after a while. Different chapters offer different level styles, but they don't differ enough to revilatise each chapter as a unique area. On subsequent playthroughs, the difficulty is stepped up, but only because there are more enemies with more health. I liked this game, but to me it doesn't have much replay value.

29311183.review:
TL;DR - Tepid recommendation for co-op if on sale

+ Twin stick mechanics are spot-on
+ Fun weapons, some of which will be familiar to Crimsonland players
+ No bugs in co-op play that I came across
+ Largely destructible environment is a great mechanic, especially during boss battles
+ Great retro soundtrack

+/- Loot system tries to straddle a grab-n-go weapon system (like Crimsonland) but with some RPG-lite elements.  In my opinion it doesn't do either well, and should have stuck to one or the other.
+/- Boss battles are tolerable, with the different phases not really differing much in strategy or challenge.
+/- Story has potential, but is largely meh

- Limited camera view; camera doesn't elevate to accommodate co-op players when they spread out, and your movement is limited to the camera view.  This results in lots of entrapment on screen that require your buddies to come back for you.  
- In co-op,  you're getting shot at from off-screen the majority of the time (see camera issue above)
- Environment and art style, while cool, gets repetitive
- Little variation in level design, except that later in the run, many more rooms to become purposeless with enemies but no loot, keys, etc.

-- In co-op, you don't get any more health help in the levels than in solo.  I feel like this is a major oversight.  For solo it's dialed in just right in my opinion, but for co-op, the difficulty of keeping your health up far exceeds the difficulty of any other aspect of the game.  This, along with the camera issues mentioned above that ensure you're getting shot at by off-screen enemies, make it a very frustrating co-op experience.

This game was fun in co-op for a few hours, eventually becoming too frustrating due to the above issues and without any real great reward system to keep us going.  I'd say it has about $5-worth of co-op fun in it.

29190080.review:
If you enjoy Shadowrun, you should get this game. The music is that haunting, ballad-esque outrun style that almost tells a short story on it's own with no lyrics. The atmosphere is grim and entertaining without becoming too repetitive. The combat is awesome for a twin-stick style shooter. 

It's a "roguelike" as we've come to know them; get as far as you can while collecting money to buy upgrades to get as far as you can next time. Though this one handles the story aspect of a loop in a sort of clever way, and you can basically swap between your "NG" and "NG+[...]" status before each run if you want. 

There's a large variety of weapons each with their own qualities that you may like or not, and from what I can tell they are all balanced very well. The only aspect that doesn't quite make sense to me is the DPS calculation you see when you compare weapons, which you do by standing over one  you could pick up. Say weapon A has a higher rate of fire, a higher base damage, and a higher crtit chance, but a lower "level," sometimes the DPS will show as less than weapon B for some reason. Maybe I'm missing something. 

The combat is incredibly satisfying. Burst fire weapons, shotguns, etc, they have an impact. I don't know if it's just visual or if it's the visual combined with the immense ramping of damage that comes with hitting multiple shots for X damage and crit modifiers and seeing enemies just drop, but it feels really good. the maneuvering is great, the AI sort of works like a time-warped stealth mechanic in other games. If humans lose you, they drop pursuit and sort of pathfind around less intently which allows you to lure them if you need to, and their pathfinding in general allows you to slip them. IE: dart around a corner and double back through a hallway to end up behind them before they get to the corner, and sometimes this is absolutely necessary.

 When you do things like this it just feels really good, from picking up the loot to meleeing a rocket out of the air at the last second, this is basically a twin-stick shooter in the Shadowrun universe, unofficially, but even without the "outrun" style it would be a damn good twin-stick on it's own.

29149771.review:
Neon Chrome is pretty good top-down shooter with strong cyberpunk theme and procedural levels.

The core gameplay is extremely solid, the controls are tight and the fights are often quite fun, especially the bosses. There's also a decent variety of weapons and several different classes that feel fairly different.

Each time you die your current character is gone, but you keep all the money you have collected and can then spend it on permanent stat upgrades and loot for your next character. While a good idea in theory (similar system was great in Rogue Legacy), in practice the upgrades are extremely boring and simply make the game feel needlessly grindy.

The game could have also used more variety with both the levels and the enemies. As it is, I had fun during my first playthrough but felt that there was little point progressing to Overseer 2.0 or higher difficulties as the game starts feeling quite repetitive.

Despite these issues I'd still recommend Neon Chrome to fans of top-down shooters. It's great fun for a few hours, even if the experience grows stale after a while.

I played through the game once on Overseer 1.0 difficulty. I was mainly using the hacker class and the playthrough took me a total of 5 hours.

The good:
- Fun gameplay
- Nice soundtrack
- Several different classes
- Destructible environments (unfortunately a lot of the walls are unbreakable)
- Keyboard+Mouse controls are tight and smooth, I didn't try the game with a controller

The bad:
- Stat upgrade system is quite grindy and boring
- Classes and weapons feel a little bit unbalanced
- Insufficient enemy variety

I wake up, march into a room and get attacked, because a voice calls me obsolete, broken. I shoot back. I can't go anywhere i want. I go from objective to objective until I die. If I do, someone else will wake up and fight instead of me. And he might be more prepared for this than I am. Hundreds of bodies lay there, waiting, sleeping, being enhanced and improved, getting enhancements installed in them , getting the gear i collect as i try to survive.
I am a mere unit, very much disposable. I always was, I'm a soldier. I was always taught that i have a choice, to kill or to be killed. My mistakes carry on with me, this healing station might be the last i will see in my life, no matter how short it might end up being, because i don't know what will get me off guard.
My master drew the path for me and I can't go back.
Are you watching me? I made a mistake, I'm hurt, but I still feel you watch me. It'll be just a few more floors before I'm done... But you know what. I'll do my best playing by your rules, not because i obey your orders, but because that's who I am.
I wake up, march into a room and get attacked, because a voice calls me obsolete, broken. I... Have.... skills that are not my own... And a gun that is nothing like the ones around. Yet i'm too weak, too slow to use it. I'm wasted. I do mistakes. I don't care that I disappoint you. I fail.
I wake up, march into a room and get attacked, because a voice calls me obsolete, broken. You expect too much from me,i'm just an engineer. I fail.
I wake up, march into a room and get attacked, because a voice calls me obsolete, broken. There floors repeat themselves, yet they don't. I use my skills to uncover the truth. I fail.
I wake up, march into a room and get attacked, because a voice calls me obsolete, broken. I shoot back. I'm here against my will, but following orders... That's something i'm used doing. You want this job done? You wasted no expense on augmenting me. You gave me the last gear you could afford. Well. I'm here. Let's see how good i am.

This game leaves me with an existential crisis. 
I guess that's better than nothing.
Solid, though wish there was a bit more interactivity with the enviroment.

Per essere uno che odia i Roguelike (specialmente il permadeath), devo dire che Neon Chrome è un ottimo esempio di come si può fare un gioco impegnativo senza essere frustrante e ripetitivo. Le meccaniche sono puramente arcade, ma con la possibiloità di abbattere i muri, si può anche cogliere il nemico di sorpresa. Non si può portare più di un'arma alla volta quindi fate attenzione alla caratteristiche quando ne trovate una nuova.
Come nei roguelike, I livelli sono generati casualmente, sono casuali le tre classi da scegliere all'inizio e gli upgrade che si trovano nei livelli. 
Se si muore si ricomincia da capo ma con i soldi guadagnati si possono comprare degli upgrade permanenti come salute, energia, danno o slot per le abilità. 
Ogni 5 livelli c'è un boss, superato il quale si passa al piano successivo. L'aspetto interessante è che ad ogni boss si sblocca il piano superiore, quindi se si muore si può ricominciare dal piano sbloccato e non tutto dall'inizio. Dopo il quinto livello è anche possibile comprare l'arma, l'attacco secondario e un'abilità con cui ricominciare. Anche questi acquisti sono permanenti.  
Tirando le somme, Il gioco tiene le caratteristiche dei roguelike che li rende divertenti e smussa il permadeath che onestamente trovo frustrante: gusto mio personale ovviamente, c'è chi ci gode a rifare un gioco 400 volte dall'inizio.
Le ambientazioni cyberpunk sono ben fatte e il livello di sfida è ben equilibrato. Direi consigliato, specialmente nei periodi di saldi.

28315140.review:
This is a very polished blend of roguelike arpg and top-down shooter. Unlike some roguelikes, this has persistant unlocks and stat upgrades, which allows for a feeling of progress even when restarting. The different classes offer a nice variety of playstyles and the wide range of cybernetic upgrades effectively allow you to customise your character (or 'asset') throughout a game.

It's also a lot more immersive than the screenshots suggest. I think that this is largely due to the excellent sound design. There is an impressive attention to detail here, eg different weapon types have a satisfyingly distinctive sound and the pitch of a weapon will change when the clip is running low, the synth soundtrack changes to elevator music as you get close to an elevator etc. There are also some great graphical touches, such as being able to see the falling rain in the Bladerunner-like city outside.

It has a similar atmosphere and look to the excellent Brigador, but my impression is that Neon Chrome is somewhat more polished and definitely more accessible to casual players (but of course it's also a different type of game). Unlike Brigador, Neon Chrome automatically saves your progress if you have to leave mid-game (hint: use the 'Exit' option, not  'Disconnect'), which is an essential feature for casual players.

28277675.review:
Having played hundreds of hours of [i]Crimsonland[/i] in the past, I heard about [i]Neon Chrome[/i] and my interest was piqued.

[i]Neon Chrome[/i] is essentially the [i]Crimsonland[/i] game transposed into a linear level based structure with a (slight) story, set within a cyberpunk world. A top down, twin stick shooter with numerous ways to outfit and upgrade your protagonist for a variety of simple but satisfying virtual violence.

I have to say that I'm a little bit dissapointed that there hasn't been a tremendous amount of innovation or evolution in the years between the two games. [i]Crimsonland[/i] was fairly deep for a twin stick shooter. I was hoping for more clever game mechanics added into the formula here.

The story is about as thin as you can get and still call it a story. Maybe I'm being generous there. However, the hammy evil megalomaniac antagonist is pretty entertaining and cartoonishly sinister.

It is good, and I will probably be playing it on and off for a while, but I'd really hope for more from 10tons in the future.

If you're looking for a bit of casual shooter ultraviolence that you don't have to think too much about to play, this is your ticket

28226240.review:
[h1]Neon Chrome::: The perfect loop?[/h1]

There comes a time in every AAA addicts' library when everything starts to feel samey and me-too. When hunting variably nonsensical objects around a gorgeously produced, big-budget-world starts losing its' flair. A time when the easy infinite death->rebirth of most modern games begs the question: if nothing happens when i die, then why try to stay alive? 

All of these issues are solved with one simple, indie, twin stick shooter. This game will make you remember why skill matters in a single player game (though it's got co-op here too, if that's your speed). Though you'll quickly find satisfaction in the simple design, the geniusly paced levels and excellent boss encounters; it's the inclusion of the roguelike feedback loop of progression that sells it for me.  That loop involves levelling aspects of your randomly rolled, cheekily named and classed character that are permanent to the game regardless of how far you made it last game, the cash you had upon death and the unlocks you discovered during your play will carry onto the next avatar.  All of this happens automatically while blasting fools and leveling your weapons (which happens per run), and while the levels seem to be 'seeded' in such a way, they still manage to feel designed by hand rather than tossed together by a ruleset.  All of this makes each play feel fresh and accomplished and satisfying, and every tense moment worthwhile.  Reaching another checkpoint between "chapters" automatically unlocks access to warp at the beginning of your next run from that level or any other previous level, these chapters at first last first 5 levels, then get longer as you get further into the game.  Just a few days in and i can already feel myself becoming more strategic in my approaches.  If you have played roguelike games then you know what i'm talking about, but if not,  the important takeaway is that you never feel like you start from the same spot essentially, in addition to the levels rerolling the sense of progress carried from one playthrough to the next is tweaked so that you can always have another leap in levels within reach, all the while managing to communicate via simple skill improvements that you're always getting better and more capable.

Being one of those AAA addicts that i mentioned in the first paragraph, it's so refreshing to find an honest, skill-based shooter that leans on the generous side of rewarding, keeping things lively from the first moment until you realize you've spent half a day playing one game.  

Bought it on sale, had i known it was this well designed and downright FUN, i would've gladly paid double. I know it's a small game, I know it looks a little silly even in some of the screenshots, but believe me none of these things matter once you get into the game, it harkens back to a standard you probably completely forgot, tasting overall a bit like the cyberpunk offspring of 'Gauntlet' and 'Smash TV'.  After a handful of unexpectedly engaging marathon sessions, you'll still be asking yourself: "why is it that some great games are barely on the radar, while other bloatedly shiny yet mediocre ones hog the limelight so often?" 

Check this game out if you're a fan of rewarding arcade-style twinstick shooters that keep you hooked.  Best budget purchase in my library in YEARS.  Highly recommended.

Топ-даун(твин-стик)-шутер от создателей культового Crimsonland'а.
Ожидал примерно того же, лишь с поправкой на замкнутые помещения. В действительности всё оказалось куда интереснее.

Вариативность геймплея приятно поражает. Сначала кажется, что разница от выбранного класса/оружия/перков очень минорна. Но потом открываются интересные виды оружия, меняющие стиль боя (в том числе и вовсе предоставляющие альтернативу прямым столкновениям). Открываются новые перки, среди которых есть действительно привносящие видимые изменения в игровой процесс. Замечаешь, что разрушаемые стены здесь не для декорации, а для тактических манёвров. Осознаешь, что стелс проработан куда лучше, чем, вероятно, показалось на первый взгляд. Начинаешь, в итоге, понимать как и что с чем эффективно комбинировать для выбранного стиля прохождения.

Ну и вообще у нас тут вроде как рогалик. Уровни процедурно-генерируемые (но есть и множество «специальных» уровней с необычными условиями и секретами). Смерть персонажа перманентна (но заработанные за прохождение деньги можно потратить на постоянные прибавки к параметрам). После каждого прохождения игры открывается новый уровень сложности. Разнообразия контента хватит надолго. Реиграбельность на высоте.

Киберпанковский сеттинг проработан на отлично. И картинка, и звук, и музыка — всё очень органично.

Чуть-чуть побраню, разве что, ИИ противников. Вообще, по меркам жанра, враги действуют очень неплохо. Но с учётом достойно проработанного стелса хотелось бы чуть большего.

Кстати, разработчики активно прислушиваются к сообществу и регулярно балуют патчами, шлифующими баланс. Что приятно.
